clinical_study.official_title: Semi-quantitative Cough Strength Score: Prediction of Extubation Outcome in Mechanically Ventilated Trauma Patients

brief_summary.textblock: Cough strength score will give true prediction of Extubation outcome

detailed_description.textblock: Patients were evaluated for readiness to be weaned off mechanical ventilation. If they had completed an Spontaneous Breathing Trial (SBT) before extubation. To measure Semiquantitative Cough Strength Score (SCSS), the investigator will put the patients at 30° to 45°, measure SCSS, first. The investigator enhance the patient to cough with as much effort as, when the investigator disconnect the ventilator. The cough strength was scored from 0 to 5 as follows: 0 = no cough on command, 1 = audible movement of air through the endotracheal tube but no audible cough, 2 = weakly (barely) audible cough, 3 = clearly audible cough, 4 = stronger cough and 5 = multiple sequential strong coughs.

primary_outcome.measure: Extubation outcome (success or failure), is the patient reintubate again or not and it's correlation with the level of Cough Strength Score
primary_outcome.description: The cough strength was scored from 0 to 5 as follows: 0 = no cough on command, 1 = audible movement of air through the endotracheal tube but no audible cough, 2 = weakly (barely) audible cough, 3 = clearly audible cough, 4 = stronger cough and 5 = multiple sequential strong coughs.

intervention.description: Evaluate extubation outcome according to degree of evaluated Semiquantitative Cough Strength Score

study_pop.textblock: The sample of this study include 60 trauma patients from both sex of critically ill mechanically ventilated patient admitted to trauma Intensive Care Unit (ICU).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are ready to be weaned off mechanical ventilation after a successful spontaneous breathing trial (SBT)
- Age : 18-65 yrs
- Mechanical ventilation more than 24hrs
- Glasgow Coma Scale:12-15
Exclusion Criteria:
- excluded those patients who were less than 18 years old
- patients had experienced less than 24hrs of mechanical ventilation.
- Patients who had undergone tracheotomy before extubation
- Chronically ill patients (Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease patients, lung cancer )
